element.element: The annual mean temperature approximates the total energy inputs for an ecosystem.
B02 - Mean Diurnal Range (Mean of monthly (max temp - min temp))
This index can help provide information pertaining to the relevance of temperature fluctuation for different species.

Isothermality quantifies how large the day-to-night temperatures oscillate relative to the summer- to-winter (annual) oscillations. An isothermal value of 100 indicates the diurnal temperature range is equiva- lent to the annual temperature range, while anything less than 100 indicates a smaller level of temperature variability within an average month relative to the year. A species distribution may be influenced by larger or smaller temperature fluctuations within a month relative to the year and this predictor is useful for ascertaining such information.
Temperature seasonality is a measure of temperature change over the course of the year. The larger the value, the greater the variability of temperature.
B05 - Max Temperature of Warmest Month
This information is useful when examining whether species distributions are affected by warm temperature anomalies throughout the year.
B06 - Min Temperature of Coldest Month
This information is useful when examining whether species distributions are affected by cold temperature anomalies throughout the year.
This information is useful when examining whether species distributions are affected by ranges of extreme temperature conditions.
B08 - Mean Temperature of Wettest Quarter
This index provides mean temperatures during the wettest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
B09 - Mean Temperature of Driest Quarter
This index provides mean temperatures during the driest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
B10 - Mean Temperature of Warmest Quarter
This index provides mean temperatures during the warmest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
B11 - Mean Temperature of Coldest Quarter
This index provides mean temperatures during the coldest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
Annual total precipitation approximates the total water inputs and is therefore useful when ascertaining the importance of water availability to a species distribution.
The wettest month is useful if extreme precipitation conditions during the year influence a species potential range.
The driest month is useful if extreme precipitation conditions during the year influence a species potential range.

Since species distributions can be strongly influenced by variability in precipitation, this index provides a percentage of precipitation variability where larger percentages represent greater variability of precipitation.
This index provides total precipitation during the wettest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
This index provides total precipitation during the driest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
This index provides total precipitation during the warmest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
This index provides total precipitation during the coldest three months of the year, which can be useful for examining how such environmental factors may affect species seasonal distributions.
watts per square metre per day
This is the annual mean solar radiation.
watts per square metre per day
This is the highest weekly solar radiation.
watts per square metre per day
This is the lowest weekly solar radiation.
This is the Radiation Seasonality (Coefficient of Variation).
watts per square metre per day
This is the solar radiation of wettest quarter.
watts per square metre per day
This is the solar radiation of driest quarter.
watts per square metre per day
This is the solar radiation of warmest quarter.
watts per square metre per day
This is the solar radiation of coldest quarter.
This is the annual mean moisture index.
This is the highest weekly moisture index.
This is the lowest weekly moisture index.
B31 - Moisture Index Seasonality (Coefficient of Variation)
This is the moisture index seasonality (coefficient of variation).
B32 - Mean Moisture Index of the Wettest Quarter
This is the annual mean moisture index of the wettest quarter.
B33 - Mean Moisture Index of the Driest Quarter
This is the annual mean moisture index of the driest quarter.
B34 - Mean Moisture Index of the Warmest Quarter
This is the annual mean moisture index of the warmest quarter.
B35 - Mean Moisture Index of the Coldest Quarter
This is the annual mean moisture index of the coldest quarter.
Clay is a useful proxy for defining the nutritional and biological capacity of soil.
The soil bulk density, also known as dry bulk density, is the weight of dry soil divided by total soil volume. This is a useful indication of a soils physical condition.

Soil pH is a measure of the concentration of hydrogen ions in the soil solution. The lower the pH of soil, the greater the acidity. pH is measured on a logarithmic scale from 1 to 14, with 7 being neutral.
This index provides the maximum amount of plant available water a soil can provide. This is an indicator of a soil's ability to retain water and make it sufficiently available for plant use.
soil class as per the ASC orders

This is a 'best of' dataset of dominant soil order according to the Australian Soil Classification. Soil Order code list: 01. AN Anthroposol, 02. CA Calcarosol, 03. CH Chromosol, 04. DE Dermosol, 05. FE Ferrosol, 06. HY Hydrosol, 07. KA Kandosol, 08. KU Kurosol, 09. OR Organosol, 10. PO Podosol, 11. RU Rudosol, 12. SO Sodosol, 13. TE Tenosol, 14 .VE Vertosol.

An index of inherent rock fertility by de Vries (2009) for the 1:1 million geology of Australia (Raymond 2009) based on a scheme from the Broad classification of Parent Material for Pedologic Purposes (Gray and Murphy 1999). The scheme ranks lithological types on a 1 to 6 scale from rocks that are extremely siliceous (>90% silica) with an extremely low base content (<3% Ca, Mg, Fe oxides) to those that are ultramafic (<45% silica and >30% base content). The original data range (1-6) has been multiplied by 2: values now range from very low fertility (2) to very high fertility (12). Rock voids without data including lakes were filled by neighbourhood statistics.
logarithm to base 10 millions of years

Mean geological age (logarithm to base 10 millions of years before present) derived from the 1:1 million surface geology of Australia (Raymond 2009) by combining the descriptive geological age fields with the timescales database (Laurie et al. 2008) to assign numerical ages to each map unit.

Pre-European estimate of mean annual store of soil organic carbon. This is the basic measure of the store of soil organic matter on the landscape. Like plant and litter carbon stores, the soil carbon stores are strongly controlled by Net Primary Production (NPP), and hence by rainfall and saturation deficit. All these C stores are also modulated by temperature because low temperatures slow the decay of plant material and high temperatures promote rapid decay. Typically, most soil carbon occurs in the upper soil layer.
Pre-European estimate of mean annual store of total plant-available soil phosphorus.
National Scale Vegetation Assets, States and Transitions (VAST Version 2) - 2008

This index classifys vegetation according to its degree of anthropogenic modification from a natural state. Class 1 sets the benchmark where classes 2 - 6 represent largely unchanged through to total removal of vegetation.

This layer is a topographic index designed to identify high flat areas at a range of scales. Zero values indicate areas that are steep or low, with values 1 and larger indicating progressively larger areas of high flat land.

This layer is a topographic index designed to identify areas of deposited material. Zero values indicate erosional terrain with values 1 and larger indicating progressively larger areas of deposition.

Dynamic Land Cover - Original classification (34 classes)
This layer provides a thematically comprehensive land cover reference for Australia. This information is an important addition to assessing habitat suitability with regards to species distributions.
Dynamic Land Cover - Reduced classification (5 classes)

This is a layer generated by the BCCVL to reduce the number of classes compared to the original DLC layer. Land cover classes are categorised in 5 high-level classes that indicate whether the area is covered by herbs, shrubs, forest, woodland or non-natural vegetation/water bodies.
Annual maximum Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) trend
The annual maximum EVI value is related to the maximum leaf area (including both canopy cover and ground cover) observed at any point during a year.
Annual minimum Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) trend
The annual minimum EVI relates to the minimum observed levels of photosynthetic activity for that location in the landscape throughout the year.
Annual mean Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI) trend
For areas that support vegetation (i.e. not salt lakes and open water bodies) the trend in the mean provides an estimate of how total photosynthetic activity is changing from year to year.
The Aridity Index can be used to quantify precipitation availability over atmospheric water demand. Generally, an AI value of <0.03 = hyper arid where a value of >0.65 = humid.
This layer is a measure of the ability of the atmosphere to remove water through Evapo-Transpiration (ET) processes.

Monthly total class A pan evaporation. Pan evaporation is a measurement that combines or integrates the effects of several climate elements: temperature, humidity, rain fall, drought dispersion, solar radiation, and wind, and is useful for estimating water need and use.

This dataset describes the altitude, as elevation (metres) above sea level. This layer can be a helpful inclusion when modelling species distributions that may be limited by elevation or subsequent climatic conditions at these elevations.
mole of carbon dioxide per square metre
GPP is the amount of carbon fixed during photosynthesis by all producers in an ecosystem.

fPAR is the fraction of photosythetically active radiation intercepted by the sunlit vegetation canopy. It is a good measure of vegetation greenness which can be used to analyse biomass production, carbon storage, habitat quality and disturbance regimes.

Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (fPAR) (Coefficient of Variance)

fPAR is the fraction of photosythetically active radiation intercepted by the sunlit vegetation canopy. It is a good measure of vegetation greenness which can be used to analyse biomass production, carbon storage, habitat quality and disturbance regimes.
This value describes the environmental suitability of a location for a species to be present.
This value describes the probability of a species occurring in a given location.
This value describes whether a species is present in a given location.
Clamping Mask is the number of variables that are out of their calibrating/training range.
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying carbonate sedimentary rocks (examples include limestone, marl, dolomite).
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying igneous rocks (examples include felsic, mafic, ultramafic intrusives and extrusives).
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying metamorphic rocks (examples include slate, schist, gneiss, serpentinite, hornfels).
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying old rocks (>570My).
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying other sedimentary rocks (examples include volcanogenic sediments, non-carbonate chemical sediment, organic-rich rocks).
Percentage of mixed sedimentary and igneous rocks
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying mixed sedimentary and igneous rocks.
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying siliciclastic/undifferentiated sedimentary rocks (examples include sandstones, conglomerate, mudstone, siltstone).
Areal proportion of all grid cells overlying unconsolidated material (regolith).
A quantitative measure of a saturated soil's ability to transmit water when subjected to a hydraulic gradient, also described as the ease with which pores of a saturated soil permit water movement.
Average Solum Plant Available Water Holding Capacity

A measure of the amount of water that can be hold for crop use, here calculated as the sum of the capacities for soil horizons A and B (topsoil and subsoil), which are calculated as (field capacity – wilting point)*horizon depth.
Average percent clay in the soil A horizon
Average percentage of clay in the A soil horizon, which refers to the topmost mineral horizon, also known as 'topsoil'. This layer is known as the zone in which the most biological activity occurs.
Average percent clay in the soil B horizon
Average percentage of clay in the B soil horizon, which is commonly referred to as the 'subsoil'. Plant roots penetrate through this layer, but it has little humus.
Average percent sand in the soil A horizon
Average percentage of sand in the A soil horizon, which refers to the topmost mineral horizon, also known as 'topsoil'. This layer is known as the zone in which the most biological activity occurs.
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean Temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Hottest month maximum temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Coldest month minimum temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Wettest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Driest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Coldest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean rainfall' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Wettest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Driest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Warmest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Coldest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
megajoule per square metre per day
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean solar radiation' of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and associated valley bottoms
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean Temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Hottest month maximum temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Coldest month minimum temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Wettest quarter mean temperature" of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Driest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter "Coldest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean rainfall' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Wettest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Driest quarter mean temperature' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Warmest quarter mean rainfall' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Coldest quarter rainfall' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell
megajoule per square metre per day
Average value of BIOCLIM parameter 'Annual mean solar radiation' of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point cell

Average growth index value calculated for C4 megatherm plants as the product of three component indices (temperature, light and moisture). The index rates the potential for plant growth between 0 (completely limiting) and 1 (non-limiting).

Average growth index value calculated for C3 mesotherm plants as the product of three component indices (temperature, light and moisture). The index rates the potential for plant growth between 0 (completely limiting) and 1 (non-limiting).

Average growth index value calculated for C3 microtherm plants as the product of three component indices (temperature, light and moisture). The index rates the potential for plant growth between 0 (completely limiting) and 1 (non-limiting).
Average growth index seasonality value (coefficient of variation) calculated for C4 megatherm plants.
Average growth index seasonality value (coefficient of variation) calculated for C3 mesotherm plants.
Average growth index seasonality value (coefficient of variation) calculated for C3 microtherm plants.
megajoule-millimetre per hectare per hour per year
Average value of the rainfall erosivity R-factor of all grid cells comprising the stream segment and its sub-catchment.
Sum of the area of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point.
Catchment area divided at stream bifurcations
Sum of the area of all grid cells upstream of the center of the stream segment pour-point divided at stream bifurcations in the ratio of 8 river:4 creeks:1 unnamed streams:0.1 floodplain wetlands.
Maximum elevation value of all upstream grid cells.
Mean elevation value of all upstream grid cells.
Catchment relief calculated as (mean upstream elevation-pour point elevation) / (max upstream elevation-pour point elevation).
Average value of all grid cells upstream of the segment pour-point.
Proportion of upstream grid cells that are valley bottoms.

Re = Dc / L where Dc = the diameter of a circle with the same area as the catchment area upstream of the segment, L = the maximum length of the catchment along a line basically parallel to the main stem (Gordon et al., 1992).
Catchment relief ratio calculated as (maximum upstream elevation-pour point elevation) / (flow path distance from source).
Strahler stream order, order not incremented for rejoining anabranches,stream order allowed to increment downstream of a confluence with one or more DEM connectors.
Maximum elevation value of all grid cells comprising the stream segment.
Mean elevation value of all grid cells comprising the stream segment.
Minimum elevation value of all grid cells comprising the stream segment.
The slope of the stream segment calculated as the stream segment elevation range / length of segment.
Average slope of downstream flow path

Average slope from one grid cell to the next in the direction of flow downstream to the stream outlet (either the sea or an internal sink). At stream bifurcations direction is always that to the main channel.
Maximum slope in downstream flow path
Maximum slope from one grid cell to the next in the direction of flow downstream to the stream outlet. At stream bifurcations direction is always that to the main channel.

Maximum flow path length upstream to the segment pour-point, calculated by incrementing the maximum upstream length of neighbouring contributing cells. Flow path distance is the distance to move across the surface, allowing for the change in elevation, from the centre of the grid cell to the centre of the next grid cell downstream in the direction of flow.

Maximum flow path length downstream to the stream outlet (either the sea or an internal sink). Flow path distance is the distance to move across the surface, allowing for the change in elevation, from the centre of the grid cell to the centre of the next grid cell downstream in the direction of flow. At stream bifurcations direction is always that to the main channel.
Mean aspect of the stream segment grid cells (computed by taking the mean of the northerly and easterly components of the direction of flow separately).

Percentage of stream segment grid cells and their immediate neighbours that are not valley bottoms as defined by mrVBF (Multi-resolution Valley Bottom Flatness) and mrRTF (Multi-resolution Ridge Top Flatness) indices.
Areal proportion of grid cells with extant (present day) bare cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with extant (present day) forests cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with extant (present day) grasses cover.
Percentage extant vegetation cover with no data values
Areal proportion of grid cells with no data values for extant (present day) vegetation cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with extant (present day) woodland cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with extant (present day) shrub cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with natural (pre-1750) bare cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with natural (pre-1750) forests cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with natural (pre-1750) grasses cover.
Percentage natural vegetation cover with no data values
Areal proportion of grid cells with no data values for natural (pre-1750) vegetation cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with natural (pre-1750) shrub cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells with natural (pre-1750) woodland cover.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is modified land (i.e. not conservation).
Areal proportion of grid cells that is irrigated land.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for aquaculture.
Percentage used for intensive animal production
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for intensive animal production.
Percentage used for intensive plant production
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for intensive plant production.
Percentage where herbicides/pesticides are likely to be used
Areal proportion of grid cells with land uses where herbicides/pesticides are likely to be used.
Percentage where fertilzer is likely to be used
Areal proportion of grid cells with land uses where fertilizer is likely to be used.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for forestry.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for mining.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is urban.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is used for irrigation supply/drainage.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is an artificial impoundment.
Areal proportion of grid cells that is a road.
Percentage with population density greater than 1 person/km2
Proportion of grid cells with population density greater than 1 person/km2.
Percentage with population density greater than 10 persons/km2
Proportion of grid cells with population density greater than 10 persons/km2.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Average of the grid cell values of “Base” (pre-1788) Net Primary Production upstream of the center of the segment pour-point cell.
Accumulated upstream values of the Sub-catchment Disturbance Index adjusted by an estimate of the sub-catchments relative contribution to total run-off.
Rating for the indirect impact of human modifications in the sub-catchments.

Rating for the disturbance of direct alterations to the flow regime such as dams, levee banks or flow diversions. This index is based on the Impoundment factor, Flow Diversions factor and Levee bank factor.
Accumulated values of the upstream Segment Flow Regime Disturbance Index adjusted by an estimate of the relative run-off accumulated at the points of disturbance.
Overall rating for river disturbance standardized between 0 (undisturbed) and 1 (severe disturbance) based on the combination of the Catchment Disturbance Index and the Flow Regime Disturbance Index.
Sub-catchments - Point source factor (maximum of all data)

The point source factor reflects the impact of an extractive industry point source, calculated based on weighted categories ranging from high impact (operating mines, contaminated sites, chemical and nutrient point pollution) to low impact (abandoned mine/quarry/petroleum well) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.

The land use factor is calculated as the proportion of the sub-catchment with land cover alterated post European settlement, weighted according to the relative impact of the land use on the stream, ranging from 1 (heavy impact, e.g. cleared for urban and cropping) to 0 (uncleared land).
Indicates whether a levee bank was present within 500 m of the stream segment.

The settlement score reflects both the density of settlements within a sub-catchment and their proximity to the stream. It is calculated based on weighted categories of settlements and structures according to the assumed level of impact on a stream. NWI = National Wilderness Inventory.

The settlement score reflects both the density of settlements within a sub-catchment and their proximity to the stream. It is calculated based on weighted categories of settlements and structures according to the assumed level of impact on a stream.

The settlement score reflects both the density of settlements within a sub-catchment and their proximity to the stream. It is calculated based on weighted categories of settlements and structures according to the assumed level of impact on a stream.
Sub-catchments - Settlement factor (maximum of all data)

The settlement score reflects both the density of settlements within a sub-catchment and their proximity to the stream. It is calculated based on weighted categories of settlements and structures according to the assumed level of impact on a stream.

The infrastructure factor is calculated based on weighted categories of infrastructure ranging from high impact (main sealed roads) to low impact (walking tracks) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream. NWI = National Wilderness Inventory.

The infrastructure factor is calculated based on weighted categories of infrastructure ranging from high impact (main sealed roads) to low impact (walking tracks) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.
Sub-catchments - Infrastructure factor (maximum of all data)

The infrastructure factor is calculated based on weighted categories of infrastructure ranging from high impact (main sealed roads) to low impact (walking tracks) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.

The impoundments factor is the maximum value of weighted factors of any impoundment features (major structures, weirs, locks/sluice gates, minor structures) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no impoundments of any type were assigned a value of zero. Off-stream impoundments, including farm dams, were generally not considered. NWI = National Wilderness Inventory.

The impoundments factor is the maximum value of weighted factors of any impoundment features (major structures, weirs, locks/sluice gates, minor structures) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no impoundments of any type were assigned a value of zero. Off-stream impoundments, including farm dams, were generally not considered.
Streams - Impoundments factor (maximum of all data)

The impoundments factor is the maximum value of weighted factors of any impoundment features (major structures, weirs, locks/sluice gates, minor structures) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no impoundments of any type were assigned a value of zero. Off-stream impoundments, including farm dams, were generally not considered.
Streams - Flow diversions factor (only NWI data)

The flow diversions factor is the maximum value of weighted factors assigned to the classes of flow diversion (major, other) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no flow diversions of any type were assigned a value of zero. NWI = National Wilderness Inventory.

The flow diversions factor is the maximum value of weighted factors assigned to the classes of flow diversion (major, other) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no flow diversions of any type were assigned a value of zero.
Streams - Flow diversions factor (maximum of all data)

The flow diversions factor is the maximum value of weighted factors assigned to the classes of flow diversion (major, other) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no flow diversions of any type were assigned a value of zero.

The infrastructure factor is calculated based on weighted categories of infrastructure ranging from high impact (main sealed roads) to low impact (walking tracks) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.
Sub-catchments - Point source factor (only NWI data)

The point source factor reflects the impact of an extractive industry point source, calculated based on weighted categories ranging from high impact (operating mines, contaminated sites, chemical and nutrient point pollution) to low impact (abandoned mine/quarry/petroleum well) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream. NWI = National Wilderness Inventory.

The point source factor reflects the impact of an extractive industry point source, calculated based on weighted categories ranging from high impact (operating mines, contaminated sites, chemical and nutrient point pollution) to low impact (abandoned mine/quarry/petroleum well) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.

The point source factor reflects the impact of an extractive industry point source, calculated based on weighted categories ranging from high impact (operating mines, contaminated sites, chemical and nutrient point pollution) to low impact (abandoned mine/quarry/petroleum well) and a distance factor to account for proximity to a stream.

The impoundments factor is the maximum value of weighted factors of any impoundment features (major structures, weirs, locks/sluice gates, minor structures) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no impoundments of any type were assigned a value of zero. Off-stream impoundments, including farm dams, were generally not considered.

The flow diversions factor is the maximum value of weighted factors assigned to the classes of flow diversion (major, other) recorded for a stream section. All stream sections with no flow diversions of any type were assigned a value of zero.
Percentage barrier free flow path length
Minimum overall barrier free flow path length percentage (damwalls, spillways, large dams and reservoirs combined).
Percentage barrier free flow path length for reservoirs
Percentage barrier free flow path length for reservoirs, calculated as ((Maximum barrier free flow path length upstream + Unrestricted distance downstream) / Total catchment length) * 100.
Percentage barrier free flow path length for damwalls, spillways or large dams

Percentage barrier free flow path length for damwalls, spillways or large dams, calculated as ((Maximum barrier free flow path length upstream + Unrestricted distance downstream) / Total catchment length) * 100.
Sum of 'distance to outlet' and 'distance to source'. Indicates total flow path length across the surface, allowing for the change in elevation, from segment pour-point to stream outlet.
Maximum barrier free flow path length upstream (reservoirs)
Maximum flow path length upstream to the segment pour-point with sinks imposed on flow pathways at the outlet of stream segments flowing out of a reservoir.

Flow path length downstream to the outlet of stream segments flowing out of a reservoir or if no reservoir the stream outlet (either the sea or an internal sink). Flow path distance is the distance to move across the surface, allowing for the change in elevation, from the centre of the grid cell to the centre of the next grid cell downstream in the direction of flow. At stream bifurcations direction is always that to the main channel.
Maximum barrier free flow path length upstream (damwalls, spillways or large dams)
Maximum flow path length upstream to the segment pour-point with sinks imposed on flow pathways at damwalls or spillways intersecting or within 100m of an AusHydro 1.1.6 WatercourseLine feature.
Unrestricted (no damwalls, spillways or large dams) distance downstream

Flow path length downstream to a damwall or spillway or if absent the stream outlet (either the sea or an internal sink). Flow path distance is the distance to move across the surface, allowing for the change in elevation, from the centre of the grid cell to the centre of the next grid cell downstream in the direction of flow. At stream bifurcations direction is always that to the main channel.
Artificial barrier presence up or downstream
Presence (1) or absence (0) of a damwall, spillway or reservoir outlet upstream and/or downstream.
Presence (1) or absence (0) of a damwall, spillway or reservoir outlet in the downstream flowpath (including anabranches).
Presence (1) or absence (0) of a damwall, spillway or reservoir outlet upstream.
Flags stream segments upstream of a segment flowing over a cliff (1 = present, 0 = absent).
Flags stream segments downstream of a segment flowing over a cliff (1 = present, 0 = absent)
Flags stream segments flowing over a waterfall (1 = present, 0 = absent).
Flags stream segments upstream of a segment flowing over a waterfall (1 = present, 0 = absent).
Flags stream segments downstream of a segment flowing over a waterfall (1 = present, 0 = absent).
Stream density calculated as total segment length of all upstream segments in the DEM derived stream network divided by the contributing area calculated for the segment pour-point.
Proportion of stream segment and associated valley bottom grid cells where a lake occupies the majority of the grid cell.
Proportion of stream segment and associated valley bottom grid cells in which a spring occurs.
Stream and valley large streams proportion
Proportion of stream segment and associated valley bottom grid cells where a large stream mapped as a watercourse area occupies the majority of the grid cell.
Proportion of stream segment and associated valley bottom grid cells in which a waterhole occurs.
Proportion of stream segment and associated valley bottom grid cells that contains one or more of a waterhole or spring or the majority of the grid cell is occupied by a lake or watercourse area.
Sum of the distances to move across the surface from each segment grid cell to the next downstream in the direction of flow.
Number of waterholes occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment.
Number of springs occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment.
Number of waterholes occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment divided by the length of the stream segment.
Number of springs occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment divided by the length of the stream segment.
Total area of lakes occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment.
Total area of lakes occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment divided by the length of the stream segment.
Segment sub-catchment area of large streams
Total area of large streams mapped as watercourse area occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment.
Total area of large streams mapped as watercourse area occurring within the stream segment sub-catchment divided by the length of the stream segment.
This value describes the difference in probability of occurrence for any given location between current and future projections.
This value indicates whether the range of a species is expanded, contracted or not changed for any given location between current and future projections.
Absolute minimum water temperature of the topmost meter of the ocean water column for the time period.
Absolute maximum water temperature of the topmost meter of the ocean water column for the time period.
Average water temperature of the topmost meter of the ocean water column over the time period.
Range of water temperatures of the topmost meter of the ocean water column calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Maximum Water Temperature of Warmest Month
Long term average of maximum water temperature of the topmost meter of the ocean water column of the warmest month.
Minimum Water Temperature of Coldest Month
Long term average of minimum water temperature of the topmost meter of the ocean water column of the coldest month.
Absolute minimum water salinity of the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum water salinity of the ocean surface for the time period.
Average water salinity of the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of water salinity of the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Maximum Water Salinity of Saltiest Month
Long term average of maximum water salinity of the ocean surface of the saltiest month.
Minimum Water Salinity of Freshest Month
Long term average of minimum water salinity of the ocean surface of the freshest month.
Absolute minimum currents velocity at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum currents velocity at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average currents velocity at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of currents velocity at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum currents velocity
Long term average of maximum currents velocity at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum currents velocity
Long term average of minimum currents velocity at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum ice thickness at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum ice thickness at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average ice thickness at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of ice thickness at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum ice thickness
Long term average of maximum ice thickness at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum ice thickness
Long term average of minimum ice thickness at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum area of the ocean covered with sea ice relative to total ocean area for the time period.
Absolute maximum area of the ocean covered with sea ice relative to total ocean area for the time period.
Average area of the ocean covered with sea ice relative to total ocean area for the time period.
Range of area of the ocean covered with sea ice calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum sea ice concentration
Long term average of maximum area of the ocean covered with sea ice relative to total ocean area.
Long term average of minimum sea ice concentration
Long term average of minimum area of the ocean covered with sea ice relative to total ocean area.

Minimum diffuse attenuation at the ocean surface for the time period. This is an indicator of water clarity, expressing how deeply visible light in the blue to the green region of the spectrum penetrates into the water column.

Maximum diffuse attenuation at the ocean surface for the time period. This is an indicator of water clarity, expressing how deeply visible light in the blue to the green region of the spectrum penetrates into the water column.

Average diffuse attenuation at the ocean surface for the time period. This is an indicator of water clarity, expressing how deeply visible light in the blue to the green region of the spectrum penetrates into the water column.
Minimum percentage of the earth covered by clouds over the time period.
Maximum percentage of the earth covered by clouds over the time period.
Average percentage of the earth covered by clouds over the time period.
Absolute minimum nitrate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum nitrate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average nitrate concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of nitrate concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum nitrate concentration
Long term average of maximum nitrate concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum nitrate concentration
Long term average of minimum nitrate concentration at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum phosphate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum phosphate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average phosphate concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of phosphate concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum phosphate concentration
Long term average of maximum phosphate concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum phosphate concentration
Long term average of minimum phosphate concentration at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum silicate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum silicate concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average silicate concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of silicate concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum silicate concentration
Long term average of maximum silicate concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum silicate concentration
Long term average of minimum silicate concentration at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum dissolved oxygen concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum dissolved oxygen concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average oxygen dissolved concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of dissolved oxygen concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum oxygen concentration
Long term average of maximum dissolved oxygen concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum oxygen concentration
Long term average of minimum dissolved oxygen concentration at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum iron concentration
Long term average of maximum dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum iron concentration
Long term average of minimum dissolved iron concentration at the ocean surface.
Average calcite (CaCO3) concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Absolute minimum chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum chlorophyll A concentration
Long term average of maximum chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum chlorophyll A concentration
Long term average of minimum chlorophyll A concentration at the ocean surface.
Absolute minimum phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface for the time period.
Absolute maximum phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface for the time period.
Average phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface over the time period.
Range of phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum phytoplankton concentration
Long term average of maximum phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum phytoplankton concentration
Long term average of minimum phytoplankton concentration expressed as carbon at the ocean surface.
gram per cubic metre per day
Absolute minimum net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface for the time period.
gram per cubic metre per day
Absolute maximum net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface for the time period.
gram per cubic metre per day
Average net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface over the time period.
gram per cubic metre per day
Range of net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface calculated as absolute maximum - absolute minimum over the time period.
Long term average of maximum primary productivity
gram per cubic metre per day
Long term average of maximum net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface.
Long term average of minimum primary productivity
gram per cubic metre per day
Long term average of minimum net primary productivity of carbon at the ocean surface.
gram per cubic metre per day
Average pH of the ocean surface for the time period. pH is an indicator of the acidity in the ocean, with lower values indicating more acid conditions and higher values more alkaline conditions.
einsteins per square meter per day

Maximum Photosynthetically Available Radiation (PAR) at the ocean surface for the time period. PAR indicates the quantum energy flux from the sun in the spectral range 400-700 nm reaching the ocean surface.
einsteins per square meter per day
Mean Photosynthetically Available Radiation at the ocean surface for the time period. PAR indicates the quantum energy flux from the sun in the spectral range 400-700 nm reaching the ocean surface.
